seo.title: Technical Strategy Quiz – Test Your Trading Knowledge | Qption
seo.description: Challenge yourself with 10 randomized questions on strategies like V-Bounce, Breakouts, Reversals, Alligator, Bollinger Bands, Moving Averages, Three Methods, Tweezers, Squat candles, and Engulfing patterns.
seo.keywords: trading quiz, technical analysis quiz, V-Bounce, breakout, reversal, Alligator, Bollinger Bands, moving average, three methods, tweezers, squat candlestick, engulfing, Qption
seo.ogTitle: Technical Strategy Quiz – Test Your Trading Knowledge
seo.ogDescription: 10 random questions each round. Learn by doing and deepen your strategy edge.
seo.twitterTitle: Technical Strategy Quiz – Test Your Trading Knowledge
seo.twitterDescription: From breakouts to reversals—prove your edge with our interactive quiz.

page.title: Technical Strategy Quiz
page.subtitle: Test your understanding of chart patterns, indicators, and trade plans. Each session pulls 10 random questions from our library and shuffles the answers to keep you sharp.

quiz.selectHint: Select an option and submit your answer.

tier.good: Nice work! Keep practicing to level up.
tier.retry: Good start — review the lessons and try again.

pool.q: In a V-Bounce setup, traders focus on price reactions at:
pool.correct: Pre-defined support or resistance zones
pool.explain: V-Bounce looks for sharp rebounds off key S/R areas to time fast entries.

pool.q: After a breakout in a V-Bounce plan, the first pullback to the broken level is often used to:
options: Confirm strength and seek continuation entries
pool.correct: Confirm strength and seek continuation entries
pool.explain: Retests (boomerangs) can confirm the breakout and offer a secondary entry.

pool.q: A 'bounce vs. break' decision at a level primarily depends on:
options: Whether the level holds or is convincingly breached
pool.correct: Whether the level holds or is convincingly breached
pool.explain: Price either respects the level (bounce) or powers through (breakout).

pool.q: The Martingale idea in trading most closely means:
options: Doubling position size after losses to recover
pool.correct: Doubling position size after losses to recover
pool.explain: Classical Martingale increases size after adverse moves to reach break-even faster—high risk.

pool.q: A key risk of Martingale is:
options: Capital can be exhausted quickly during extended adverse moves
Guaranteed profits after a few steps
It cannot be used on short timeframes
pool.correct: Capital can be exhausted quickly during extended adverse moves
pool.explain: Successive doubling rapidly grows exposure; risk controls and limits are crucial.

pool.q: A classic sign of potential reversal is:
options: Price making new highs with rising momentum
Bullish or bearish divergences versus indicators like RSI
Price touching a moving average once
A single doji anywhere on the chart
pool.correct: Bullish or bearish divergences versus indicators like RSI
pool.explain: Divergence can hint at waning momentum into new extremes—use confirmation.

pool.q: Reversal traders often look for confirmation via:
options: Structure breaks (e.g., break of a swing), volume clues, or retests
pool.correct: Structure breaks (e.g., break of a swing), volume clues, or retests
pool.explain: Structure shifts and confirmation filters reduce false turns.

pool.q: Breakouts are most credible when accompanied by:
options: Rising volume/volatility and decisive closes beyond levels
Only a wick through the level
pool.correct: Rising volume/volatility and decisive closes beyond levels
pool.explain: Energy behind the move supports continuation; watch for retest behavior.

pool.q: A common breakout tactic after a level is cleared:
options: Enter on a retest of the broken level (now S/R flip)
Wait for price to re-enter the range
pool.correct: Enter on a retest of the broken level (now S/R flip)
pool.explain: Retests can provide better risk/return with structure as invalidation.

pool.q: The Alligator indicator consists of:
options: Three smoothed averages: jaw, teeth, lips
pool.correct: Three smoothed averages: jaw, teeth, lips
pool.explain: When lines fan out and align, the 'Alligator' is awake and trending.

pool.q: When the Alligator lines are intertwined (“sleeping”), it suggests:
options: Consolidation/range—stand by for a wake-up move
pool.correct: Consolidation/range—stand by for a wake-up move
pool.explain: Intertwined lines indicate low directional clarity; wait for alignment.

pool.q: A Bollinger Band 'squeeze' generally implies:
options: Low volatility that often precedes expansion
pool.correct: Low volatility that often precedes expansion
pool.explain: Bands contract in quiet phases; breakouts after squeezes can run.

pool.q: Closes outside a Bollinger Band can indicate:
pool.correct: Momentum/volatility expansion—context needed
pool.explain: Outside touches can be strong momentum; confirm with trend/volume/structure.

pool.q: EMA vs SMA: which reacts faster to recent price?
pool.correct: EMA
pool.explain: EMA weights recent prices more heavily and turns quicker than SMA.

pool.q: A simple MA crossover buy signal is commonly:
options: Long MA crossing above short MA
Short MA crossing above long MA
pool.correct: Short MA crossing above long MA
pool.explain: Short-over-long is a basic bullish momentum cue (lagging—use filters).

pool.q: In the Rising/Falling Three Methods pattern, the small mid-candles should:
options: Close beyond the first large candle
Stay inside the range of the initial long candle
Be larger than the first candle
pool.correct: Stay inside the range of the initial long candle
pool.explain: Three small counter-trend candles inside the first bar’s range, then continuation.

pool.q: Three Methods is typically a:
pool.correct: Continuation pattern
pool.explain: It pauses the trend briefly before resuming in the same direction.

pool.q: A Tweezer Top often shows:
options: Two highs around the same level after an up-move
Two lows around the same level after a down-move
pool.correct: Two highs around the same level after an up-move
pool.explain: Equal/similar highs can signal resistance and potential reversal.

pool.q: A Tweezer Bottom often signals:
options: Potential bullish reversal with equal/similar lows
pool.correct: Potential bullish reversal with equal/similar lows
pool.explain: Equal lows can highlight demand stepping in near the same area.

pool.q: A 'Squat' candle typically combines:
pool.correct: High volume and narrow range
pool.explain: It hints at a power struggle/absorption; watch for break or reversal.

pool.q: Traders use squat candles to anticipate:
options: Potential breakout or reversal after pressure builds
pool.correct: Potential breakout or reversal after pressure builds
pool.explain: Energy coiled in a narrow bar can release directionally next.

pool.q: A Bullish Engulfing pattern occurs when:
options: A small green candle is followed by a smaller green candle
A larger green body fully covers the prior red body after a decline
A doji appears at the top
pool.correct: A larger green body fully covers the prior red body after a decline
pool.explain: Engulfing body suggests a sharp shift in control—seek confluence.

pool.q: For a Bearish Engulfing, look for:
options: A larger red body fully covering the prior green body after an advance
pool.correct: A larger red body fully covering the prior green body after an advance
pool.explain: Shows potential control shift to sellers—confirm with structure/volume.
